title: Snowstorm expected to start in Hagerstown region late Sunday: What we know
text:
Snowstorm expected to start in Hagerstown region late Sunday: What we know
The Monday morning and afternoon commutes could get messy as the National Weather Service is forecasting a few inches of snow late Sunday through Monday afternoon in the Hagerstown region, including southern Franklin County, Pa.
Meteorologists in the Baltimore/Washington and State College, Pa., forecast offices said Thursday morning it was too soon to put a number on how many inches of snow the area could get. However meteorologist Cody Ledbetter with the Baltimore/Washington office said it's likely the Hagerstown area will get at least a few inches of snow.
Ledbetter said the snow is expected to start late Sunday afternoon or evening and could linger into late Monday afternoon or evening.
Storm tracks can change that far out, but as of Thursday morning the Washington County area was expected to get all snow, with more of a wintry mix farther south.
Hagerstown Public Works Director Eric Deike said Thursday morning he was seeing reports of 1 to 3 inches of snow expected locally.
As the storm starts, crews will disperse salt on bridges and roads, Deike said. If the city gets 3 inches of snow, crews will plow the snow and distribute salt on driving surfaces, he said.
Ledbetter and meteorologist Joe Bauco with the State College forecast office said temperatures are expected to remain below freezing during the snowstorm. Ledbetter said it's expected to be "very cold" the next two weeks.
The snow is expected to stick and there's potential for black ice, Bauco said.
Deike said even with temperatures below freezing, if the sun comes out Tuesday that should help melt snow off the asphalt.
